journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Mechanical testing of technical woven fabrics

article-meta.aff: Faculty of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Gdansk University of Technology, Gdansk, Poland

author-notes.corresp: Andrzej Ambroziak, Faculty of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Gdansk University of Technology, Narutowicza 11/12, Gdansk 80-952, Poland. Email: ambrozan@pg.gda.pl

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This article presents a review of technical fabrics testing methods used by the authors on the basis of their experience with research on properties of polytetrefluoroethylene-coated fabrics used for Forest Opera in Sopot (Poland). First, the different types of testing methods used for description of mechanical properties (uniaxial tensile tests, biaxial tensile tests and shear tests) of technical woven fabrics are described. The authors present the collection of test methods and discuss the results of these tests for different fabrics. Finally, the effects of temperature on mechanical properties are studied.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Modern roofing structures should be light and cover large areas. One of the most suitable materials to fulfill these requirements is a technical (architectural) fabric. The technical woven fabrics used for structures are usually made of polyester or glass fibers covered with polyvinylchloride (PVC) or polytetrefluoroethylene (PTFE), respectively. For the membrane structure applications, fabric is one of the main materials, which plays both constructional and covering function.1 It is relatively cheap and easy to manufacture and so is the construction assembling. The problem with designing such structures is their geometrical and material nonlinearity.2 This material exhibits physical non-linearity and a special kind of anisotropy in which material properties are changing during deformation according to the change of direction of threads. Many complicated constitutive models have been invented to show these effects, especially for finite element applications.3 Non-linear constitutive models usually have many parameters that should be evaluated from complicated laboratory tests.

In the first part of this article, the authors present and compare different laboratory tests for fabrics made of polyester and glass fibers covered with PVC or PTFE. Typical tests described in national standards, which can give general characteristic of the fabric properties, are not sufficient for physically non-linear description used in the design process. The authors give a compact review of testing methods, showing results obtained from own tests and those available in chosen publications. As it is difficult to decide which particular test should be used to evaluate a certain type of non-linear constitutive model, the authors concentrate first of all on tests required by two national standards: (PN-) EN ISO 1421:20014 (similar description can be found in German DIN standards) and ASTM D7515 used in USA. Table 1 shows the main differences of the tests performance according European and ASTM D751 standards. Due to lack of standards describing this type of tests for biaxial and shear tests, the situation is even worse. Usually, such experiments are performed depending on the requirements of the institution that has made the request. Table 1.
Main differences between fabrics test standards.
PN-EN ISO 1421:2001 ASTM D751
Test rate 100 mm/min 300 mm/min
Recalculate strain rate for strips 200 mm long 8.333·10−3 1/s
Distance between clamps (grip distance) Strip length: 200 mm or 100 mm if strain exceeds 75% 75 mm
Grab test: 100 mm or 75 mm
Base method Strip test Grab test
Specimens 50 mm wide Specimens 100 mm wide and not less than 150 mm long
Alternative method Grab test Strip test
Specimens 100 mm wide and not less than 150 mm long Specimens 25 mm wide (or other width when specified)

Only restricted number of laboratory tools can be used to perform experiments. The main devices are: strength machines (for uniaxial tests), different types of biaxial testing stands (biaxial tests) and shear testing devices, usually individually designed. Several ways of testing can also be used. The easiest are the tests with constant rate of traverse (or other testing element) movement. They are called the constant displacement rate tests. Tests with constant force rate are more complicated (especially in biaxial variants). Finally, tests with constant strain rates are the most difficult. They require additional device (extensometer) and sophisticated system of two-direction test control. On the basis of these three methods of testing, several types of experiments can be invented (cyclic tests, creep test, relaxation tests, etc.).

In the second part of this article, the authors study the properties of PTFE-coated fabric Sheerfill-I used for the new roof of Forest Opera in Sopot (Poland). The tensile (uniaxial and biaxial) properties of coated fabric, as well as the effects of temperature on mechanical properties are studied. It should be noted that before reconstruction in 2009, from 1990 the roof was made from polyester fiber coated with PVC called VALMEX P50 manufactured by Mehler.

sec.title: Laboratory tests: general description
sec.p: Uniaxial tensile experiments are the basic group of laboratory tests for technical fabrics. One of the advantages of such tests is simplicity of preparation and cutting out of specimens. Usually they are made on standard strength machines using the strip (recommended in standard PN-EN ISO 14214) or grab test method (recommended in ASTM D751 Standard Test Methods for Coated Fabrics5). In both cases, there is no recommendation in standards for an extensometer application that can be especially important in the strip tests as a way to avoid the influence of close to grips breaking effect and grip sliding effect.

Two types of the most typical fabrics used for hanging roofs have been examined. The first one is manufactured from polyester yarns coated on both sides with PVC and is represented by fabrics called Panama and AF9032. The second type is manufactured from glass yarns coated with PTFE. The commercial names of the fabrics used for tests are Sheerfill-I and B18089. Experiments have been done according to the standard PN-EN ISO 14214 using the strip method. All tests have been made on strips 200 mm long with constant displacement rate of 100 mm/min. The thickness of all specimens was close to 1 mm.

The results of typical tests as strain–stress functions for polyester and glass fabrics are given in Figures 1 and 2, respectively. Both the examined polyester fabrics showed similar results. The situation is quite different for glass fabrics. In Figure 2(b), the initial (important for designers) part of the strain–stress relation is shown in detail. The result of the test reflects the way the fabric is manufactured. The Sheerfill-I fabric has been pre-tensioned in both directions during process of covering net of the yarns with the coating layers. In the case of B18089, the fabric has been pre-tensioned in the warp direction only. These results are similar in the warp direction but important reduction of the initial elasticity modulus in the weft direction can be observed. In spite of this, both fabrics have similar manufacturer declarations regarding material properties. This does not reflect their behavior in tensile tests. The elasticity modulus of the fabric is usually is not declared in such situations but this is important for designers (e.g. in finite element calculations). For some types of membrane structures (e.g. cone-shaped membranes), a weaker modulus in the weft direction can simplify the form finding stage of design but for relatively flat structures, application of Sheerfill-I fabric can be easier. Finally, the ultimate tensile strength (UTS) for warp and weft has been determined. The results given in Table 2 are similar to the manufacturer's declarations. Usually the same yarns are used as warp and weft; therefore, the ultimate strength in both directions is similar and is weakly related to the way the fabric is manufactured. The main factor influencing the ultimate strength is thickness of the yarns (related to the dead weight of the fabric), the number of yarns per width unit (expressed by the tex factor) and the material from which the yarns are made. Additionally, it should be noted that in the designing procedure, the value of the UTS is reduced.6 Based on the experience of designers, for coated fabrics, the application of the reduction of the UTS parameter can be described according to the equation (1)LTS=UTS/(γ1·γ2·γ3) Figure 1.
Uniaxial tensile tests of polyester threads technical fabrics.
Figure 2.
Uniaxial tensile tests of glass threads technical fabrics: (a) full test and (b) details of initial region.
Table 2.
Base parameters for investigated fabrics.
Density (g/m2) UTSwarp (kN/m) UTSweft (kN/m)
Panama 870 75 ± 3 60 ± 4
AF9032 1085 115 ± 5 95 ± 2
B18089 GF 1150 135 ± 4 100 ± 9
Sheerfill 1543 180 ± 12 175 ± 20

In equation (1), LTS is the value of the long-term tensile strength limit. The reduction parameter γ1 takes into account the rheological phenomenon (usually its value is close to 2.0), γ2≥1.05 takes into account environmental influence (e.g. ultraviolet radiation) and γ3≥1.05 describes individual work conditions of fabric built in a structure. The factors γ1 and γ2 are determined on the basis of laboratory tests, while parameter γ3 is specified by the designer according to the character and lifetime of structure utilization.

A fabric based on glass yarns coated with PTFE has been also investigated be Kato et al.7 The laboratory tests have been performed up to two stress levels: 24.5 and 49 kN/m. The specimens for testing have width of 240 mm, grip distance of 600 mm and gauge length of 70 mm. The same testing device has been used for uniaxial and biaxial tests. Therefore, the shape of specimens in the uniaxial test is not the same as described in the national standards. A constant displacement rate of 2 mm/min (5.555·10−5 1/s) has been used during the test. This velocity is low in comparison with the tests in this study due to the large length of specimens. Figure 3 shows the comparison of results obtained by Kato et al.7 and the results from this study for B18089 fabric, which is similar due to manufacturer specification. Despite different testing devices and test velocities, the results are in good correlation for the weft and for the warp. Figure 3.
Comparison of the uniaxial tensile tests.

Uniaxial tensile tests for Sheerfill-I have been described by Zhang et al.8 In this investigation, specimens have width of 50 mm, length of 1000 mm and gauge (extensometer) length of 200 mm. A constant displacement rate of 100 mm/min has been applied in these experiments. In Figure 4 the comparison of two types of Sheerfill fabrics is presented. More important differences can be observed here. The main reason for the differences can be different dead weight of the Sheerfill-I fabric, which is 1400 g/m2, which is less than that for the fabric investigated in this article (see Table 2). Figure 4.
Uniaxial tensile tests results for Sheerfill I8 and Sheerfill fabrics.

The application of the test results for identification of viscoplastic (see study of Kłosowski et al.9) or viscoelastic constitutive (see study of Kłosowski et al.10) equations usually requires the series of constant strain rates tests with different strain rates or a long-lasting creep (or relaxation) test. The uniaxial tensile tests with different constant strain rate are described by Zhang et al.8 for PTFE-coated fabrics (Figure 5(b)) and by Ambroziak6 for PVC-coated fabric (Figure 5(a)). They show that technical fabrics exhibit strain rate dependency. This is important in rheological models formulation. From creep tests9 (Figure 6), it can be concluded that higher stress levels cause reduction in time of rheological effects and also that modern fabrics usually do not exhibit moisture dependency. National standards such as PN-EN ISO 14214 and ASTM D7515 assume the usage of flat grips (Figure 7(a)), but for more exact tests, special types of grips for fabrics are recommended. The curve grips (Figure 7(b)) or roller grips (Figure 7(c)) help avoid close to grips breaks of specimens but they require use of extensometer, which makes tests more complicated but more precise. In Figure 8, the results of stripe tensile tests with extensometer and results obtained from tests with flat grips without extensometer are compared (polyester fibers, weft direction). A good correlation of results for small deformations has been observed. This difference grows in the case of large deformations. Figure 5.
Results of constant strain rate test for: (a) Panama weft threads and (b) polytetrefluoroethylene-coated weft threads.8
Figure 6.
Results of the creep tests (percentage of ultimate stress) for Panama warp threads.
Figure 7.
Different types of grips of strength machines: (a) flat grips, (b) curve grips and (c) rolled grips.
Figure 8.
Uniaxial tensile tests – different measurement base.

It can be concluded that the uniaxial tensile tests are described in detail by standards. In a simple way, it is possible to prepare specimens and perform tests. Different types of testing devices with different types of grips are available. Therefore, despite national standards requirements, usage of extensometers should be recommended. These tests do not depict the full work conditions of fabric in real structures but are currently used by engineers to estimate a behaviour of coated fabrics. Additionally, identification of material parameters can be performed in a simple way.

The biaxial tests (not required by national standards) are more complicated and the application of special designed devices is necessary.11,12 The machines should enable tension in two directions with different (but constant in time) force ratio. The good quality of results depends on the type of an extensometer used to measure deformation in two directions simultaneously (video-extensometer is used). In this type of test, the cross-shaped specimens are preferred. The mechanism of the tests well reflects an anisotropic character of technical woven fabrics and the results are important in design of textile structures. Several laboratories published results of these types of tests.

In Figures 9–11, the stress–strain curves obtained by Day13 for PTFE fabric for the warp to weft stress ratio 1 : 1, 5 : 1, 1 : 5 are presented. These tests have been used, e.g. by Bridgens and Gosling14 to construct stress–strain response surfaces. The biaxial tension tests for PTFE type of fabric for the warp to weft stress ratio 1 : 1, 1 : 1,5, 1 : 2, 1,5 : 1, 2 : 1 obtained by Kato et al.7 are presented in Figures 12–16. The laboratory tests for two stress levels 24.5 kN/m and 49 kN/m have been performed. The results of these experiments have been used e.g. by Pargana et al.15 to the construct constitutive models of fabric for the finite element analysis. Figure 9.
Biaxial tensile tests – weft results.
Figure 10.
Biaxial tensile tests – warp results polytetrefluoroethylene.
Figure 11.
Biaxial tensile tests for glass – fiber base technical fabrics covering polytetrefluoroethylene.
Figure 12.
Biaxial tensile tests for 1 : 1 stress ratio.
Figure 13.
Biaxial tensile tests for 1 : 1.5 stress ratio.
Figure 14.
Biaxial tensile tests for 1 : 2 stress ratio.
Figure 15.
Biaxial tensile tests for 1.5 : 1 stress ratio.
Figure 16.
Biaxial tensile tests for 2 : 1 stress ratio.

The biaxial and uniaxial tensile tests for a coated plain-weave fabric have been performed by Kumazawa et al.,16 as well as by Galliot and Luchsinger.17 They have investigated seven different types of PVC-coated polyester fabrics. For all of them the parameters have been estimated, for proposed in the paper the non-linear material model. In the biaxial tensile tests thirteen loads ratios have been applied.

The results of the biaxial tests made for AF9032 polyester fabric18 for three values of stress in the warp and weft yarns ratios: 2 : 1; 1 : 1 and 2 : 1 are available. These biaxial tensile tests are compared with the results of the uniaxial tensile tests and the biaxial tests carried out by the authors in this study and the results are shown in Figures 17–19. The results for stress ratio 1 : 1 are very similar to the results of uniaxial tests. Bigger differences were noticed only when stresses in the warp direction are two times larger than those in the weft direction. Figure 17.
Comparison of uniaxial tensile tests and biaxial tensile tests 1 : 1.
Figure 18.
Comparison of uniaxial tensile tests and biaxial tensile tests 1 : 2.
Figure 19.
Comparison of uniaxial tensile tests and biaxial tensile tests 2 : 1.

Application of the biaxial tensile tests expresses a biaxial stress state in fabric specimens and gives a good approximation of the real work conditions of fabrics. A different kind of biaxial machine can be used. Despite different devices being used for biaxial machines constructions, they have the same manner of test performance. The only difference is the value of breaking force and width of specimens that can be applied in tests. The results obtained from biaxial tests are much more difficult for the identification of material parameters. However, it is necessary to perform these tests to establish a practical working range and a value of strength, both very important for designers.

The last group of most often performed experiments are the shear tests.19–21 Here several methods can be used. The first method is based on the uniaxial or biaxial tensile tests made on specimens, which are prepared by cutting the samples with the various bias angles from the main yarns of warp and weft (Figure 20). The uniaxial tensile test results, for PTFE-coated fabrics, for the bias angles of 0o, 15o, 30o, 45o, 60o and 90o obtained in the study of Zhang et al.8 are shown in Figure 21. Here 0o and 90o angles are standard uniaxial tests along the warp and weft yarn directions. The second method for the investigation of the shear effect is the application of a T-shaped specimen (Figure 22). In this test, the pretension is applied along the two arms of a specimen, while a ‘shearing’ loading is applied along the third arm. Vysochina and Bigaud22 have performed the tests using T-shape specimens for polyester fabrics coated with PVC. The following method is called ‘frame test rig’ (see Figure 23), where a fabric sample is clamped in a square frame.23 This frame is mounted to a uniaxial strength machine and during the test, the frame is changing its shape from a square to a diamond. In these tests, the load response is very sensitive to the clamping of the fabrics. The experimental study and the mathematical analysis of the shear deformation of E-glass woven fabrics have been tested by Mohammed et al.19 and Peng and Cao.24 The other method is the Kes-F test (Kawabata Evaluation System for Fabrics) described in the study of Kawabata,25 which is a general systematic method of measuring the mechanical and surface fabrics properties. In the case of shear strength, measurement is achieved by pulling on the fabric at various angles with respect to the direction of the warp or weft yarns. Figure 20.
Unixial and biaxial tests with various bias angles.
Figure 21.
Uniaxial tensile tests results with specimens cut with different angle.
Figure 22.
Biaxial test with T-shape specimen.
Figure 23.
Jointed frame for the frame test rig.

It can be concluded that many types of shear tests and devices can be found in the literature. These types of tests are generally used when shear properties of the fabric are important in the deformation behaviour (e.g. tensairity structures). Additionally, when an orthotropic constitutive model is used, it is necessary to determine the value of shear modulus; therefore, shear tests have to be performed.

sec.title: Laboratory tests: practical application
sec.p:
The PTFE-coated fabric Sheerfill-I used for the Forest Opera roof of Sopot has been the research subject. Its thickness is about 1 mm and weight is 1543 g/m2 (see Table 2). In the process of erection of the roof, one of the fabric's subpanels has been damaged (see Figure 24). It has been suspected that low temperature (close to 0°C) during roof assembling could be the reason for this problem. The aims of the investigation are to determine the influence of temperature on strength and stiffness of the fabric as well as change in stress state due to seasonal changes in temperature. The tests have been carried out on uniaxial and biaxial strength machines. In uniaxial tests, specimens of width 50 mm; length, 200 mm; and gauge (mechanical extensometer) length, 100 mm have been used. In biaxial tests, cross-shaped specimens with cross-arm bright of 100 mm have been used. Tests have been controlled by video extensometer (in both perpendicular directions) with variable base. Figure 24.
Damaged part of roof subpanel.

Initially, the stiffness of the fabric due to influence of temperature has been controlled. Considering the various environmental conditions the building is exposed to, the following six test temperatures were selected: 70°C and 40°C (summer conditions) 23°C and 10°C (spring, autumn conditions) and 0°C and −30°C (winter conditions). Constant displacement rate of 100 mm/min has been applied in uniaxial tests. Figures 25–28 show that changes in temperature do not cause significant change in stress–strain relation in the range between 0°C and 23°C. Temperatures out of this range cause bigger changes in stress–strain relation. Also UTS for different temperatures is almost the same −190 kN/m for warp and 200 kN/m for weft. Only at temperature of −30°C for the weft and warp, increase in value of the UTS is observed. According to the results of the tests, the damage to the roof (see Figure 24) could not have been caused by change in stiffness of the fabric in low temperature conditions, rather due to mistakes in the assembling process. Figure 25.
Stress–strain warp curves under different temperatures.
Figure 26.
Stress–strain weft curves under different temperatures.
Figure 27.
Stress–strain warp curves under different temperatures – full strain range.
Figure 28.
Stress–strain weft curves under different temperatures – full strain range.

The second group of tests has been performed to answer the question: is it possible that in the assembling process workers used force bigger than that in the design project (LTS limit) to fix the fabric.

Samples have been divided into three group named:
N, samples cut from not used (virgin) part of technical fabric
NR, samples cut from not used technical fabric after 12 h creep test with tensile level of 50 kN/m, which is the value close to LTS stress
D, samples cut form damaged subpanel of technical woven fabric but not close to the damage area.

Results of uniaxial tensile tests are presented in Figure 29 for warp direction and Figure 30 for weft direction. Results of biaxial tension tests are shown in Figures 31 and 32. It can be concluded that UTS for the uniaxial tensile tests is 180–200 kN/m approximately and for the biaxial tensile tests, its value decreases to 80 kN/m. This relatively strong reduction may be caused by cross-shape of specimens used in the biaxial test (concentration of stresses in specimen's corners). The obtained results are similar to the results obtained by Zhang et al.8 for PTFE-coated fabrics, where the biaxial tensile strength is only 45–60% of the uniaxial tensile tests. Results for the D type of samples are between the results of the N samples and NR samples. It confirms that specimens cut from the damaged subpanel of the roof have not reached LTS level of stress. That means that damage of the panel has a local character. Figure 29.
Stress–strain warp curves.
Figure 30.
Stress–strain weft curves.
Figure 31.
Stress–strain warp curves – biaxial tension test.
Figure 32.
Stress–strain weft curves – biaxial tension test.

Determination of fabric behavior in extreme climatic conditions has been the next aim of laboratory tests. In summer conditions, it has been assumed that the fabric can be sun heated up to 70°C. In this case, decrease of stress state in roof membrane is expected. It has been assumed that the fabric is stretched to minimal force equal to 5 kN/m (minimal force assumed in the design project). It should be examined, if due to increase of temperature, loss of stress state to values close to zero is possible. Such a situation could be dangerous for the structure. In winter conditions (temperature close to −30°C), increase of stresses is expected. It is assumed that fabric is stretched to force close to 50 kN/m (LTS limit) in home temperature, and then temperature is decreased to −30°C. Tests have been performed on specimens cut from the damaged subpanel (to reduce rheological effects). In the first stage of test, stress of 50 kN/m (or 5 kN/m) is constant for 2 h (during this period main rheological effects are observed). Then the type of the test is changed from the constant stress to constant grip distance condition and a change of temperature is applied. In this phase, small changes in strains measured by the extensometer are still possible. After the temperature has reached a specified limit (−30°C or 70°C), the specimen conditions are held for 1–2 h (the constant grip distance). In this time, a change of stress state in fabrics is observed. For all test stress ratio, 1 : 1 in warp–weft directions has been applied.

Tests results are shown in Figures 33 and 34 for subzero temperature and in Figures 35 and 36 for high temperature. For tests in winter conditions, increase of stresses from 50 kN/m to about 62 kN/m is observed (24%). Fortunately, in Poland, in such conditions, extreme snow falls or heavy winds are not observed. The increase of temperature from room temperature to 70°C produces decrease of stress from 5 to 1.25 kN/m for the warp and to 2.25 kN/m for the weft. On the basis of obtained results, it can be concluded that unstressed state of specimen (roof membrane) is not possible at the temperature considered when 5 kN/m is assumed as the initial stress state. Figure 33.
Change of warp stress – decrease of temperature to −30°C.
Figure 34.
Change of weft stress – decrease of temperature to −30°C.
Figure 35.
Change of warp stress – increase of temperature to +70°C.
Figure 36.
Change of weft stress – increase of temperature to +70°C.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study presents the test methods for investigation of mechanical properties of technical woven fabrics. The modern laboratory equipment provides several variants of tests and usually enables computer registration of the results, which is important for future identification process. Examples of such identifications made by authors can be found in the literature indicated previously in this article. The comparison of tests results made by different laboratories on the same fabrics sometimes leads to differences in result. In scientific papers, all details of the conditions under which tests are conducted should be given. Even the manner of manufacturing of a fabric can influence its mechanical properties. New, more sophisticated models, having many parameters require more complex laboratory equipment and test methods. Examples of such tests have been presented in this article and permit a better understanding of fabric behavior.

The research program completed by authors for the needs of the construction of the new roof of Forest Opera in Sopot shows the possibilities of modern testing devices. Such tests are necessary before, during and after completion of the structure. The results of the test can explain problems that occur during roof assembly and also during its exploitation.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The authors acknowledge the National Science Centre in Cracow (Poland), Grant No. UMO-2011/03/B/ST8/06500, for the financial support of this research program.
